paper_abstract: As well known the rotation distance D(S, T) between two binary trees S, T of n vertices is the minimum number of rotations of pairs of vertices to transform S into T. We introduce the new operation of chain rotation on a tree, involving two chains of vertices, that requires changing exactly three pointers in the data structure as for a standard rotation, and define the corresponding chain distance C(S, T). As for D(S, T), no polynomial time algorithm to compute C(S, T) is known. We prove a constructive upper bound and an analytical lower bound on C(S, T) based on the number of maximal chains in the two trees. More precisely we prove the general upper bound C(S, T) <= n - 1 and we show that there are pairs of trees for which this bound is tight. No similar result is known for D(S, T) where the best upper and lower bounds are 2n - 6 and 5/3n - 4 respectively. (C) 2013 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
paper_title: Chain rotations: A new look at tree distance
